person.note: Not a central character, but referenced as a great historical deliverer, repealing unjust laws such as the edict of death to a woman pregnant out of wedlock.
Not a central character. King Arthur revoked the law condemning unwed mothers to death when he defeated Floyon.
a Queen, apparently ruling in Windsor.

The Damsel of Denmark is Oriana's personal attendant, associated with her mother Brisena who is originally from Denmark. The Damsel of Denmark is unique in that she has no first name. Her brother is the messenger Durin. In Book III she loses Oriana's illegitimate infant Esplandian to a lioness.

Helisena is Amadis of Gaul's mother and the daughter of King Garinter. She and Perion of Gaul indulged in a clandestine liaison in the first chapters of Book I (debateably a clandestine marriage). She later celebrates a public marriage to Perion and has two more children, Galaor and Melicia.

Perion of Gaul is Amadis of Gaul's father. He and Helisena indulge in a clandestine liaison (debateably a clandestine marriage) early in Book I and later marry. They have two other children, Galaor and Melicia. Perion makes clear that he considers Amadis legitimate by naming him heir over his younger brother Galaor. Perion fights in Lisuarte of Britain's wars and in his grandson Esplandian's campaign at Constantinople in Montalvo's sequel, where he dies. Amadis succeeds to the throne of Britain on Perion's death.

Darioleta is Helisena's maid. In Book I she helps Helisena hide her pregnancy and constructs the ark in which the infant Amadis floats down the river. She writes a note declaring the child's name, covers it in wax, and places it in the ark. In later episodes she and her family are imprisoned by Arcalaus and then by the giant Balan. Balan kills her son in combat, but after Amadis brokers a peace, Darioleta's daughter marries the giant's son Bravor and starts a new lineage of Christianized half-giants.

Garinter, king of Little Britain, is the father of Helisena and her sister, the Lady of the Garland. After his death the Lady of the Garland's husband, King Languines of Scotland, inherits his kingdom.

Gandales is the knight of Scotland who finds the infant Amadis in the ark. He raises Amadis until the age of six and then sends him, reluctantly, to the court of Languines. Gandales's son Gandalin is Amadis's squire and lifelong friend. Gandales should not be confused with the similarly named Galvanes Lackland (Galvanes Sin Tierra), Agrayes's uncle, or the giant Gandalaz.
The king of Scotland, Languines is married to Amadis's aunt, the Lady of the Garland. He is the father of Agrayes and Mabilia. Amadis, Oriana and Gandalin are fostered at his court in their youth.

Urganda is the good sorceress who helps Amadis in the style of the Lady of the Lake. Her magic gives her the ability to know the future, to change her appearance, and to bewitch others. In one instance one of her spells nearly causes a woman to drown herself because it made the victim feel as though she were on fire. The Urganda of Book I resembles typical fairy characters: she is vindictive, she entraps a human lover, and she protects her favorite people and punishes others with magic. From Book II onward Urganda becomes an increasingly benevolent source of deus ex machina and performs only good deeds, primarily deeds of prophecy. She tends to send her predictions by letter.

Arcalaus the enchanter is Amadis's nemesis and an enemy of Lisuarte. He imprisons Amadis by enchantment in Book I and tries to convince Lisuarte's court that he has killed the young knight in battle. Later he attempts to abduct Oriana to marry her to his son. He imprisons Amadis and Gandalin again in Book III. Urganda urges them to save his life.

Lisuarte is the king of Britain during the bulk of Amadís I-IV. He has two daughters, Oriana and Leonoreta, and a wife, Brisena. During the early portion of Amadís Book I Lisuarte is represented as a good and fair king, both a literal and metaphorical ancestor for Arthur. Like Arthur he gathers virtuous knights to his court. As the books progress Lisuarte becomes the stereotype of the bad king, tyrannical, cruel, and melancholic. He values the truth of his word but breaks promises to his elder daughter Oriana, disinheriting her in Book III for her younger sister and attempting to force her to marry el Patín (the Gosling), the incompetent emperor of Rome. In Book IV Lisuarte becomes entrapped by an enchantress while hunting; his grandson Esplandián will save him in the sequel volume Las Sergas de Esplandián (The Exploits of Esplandián).

Amadis of Gaul (Amadís de Gaula), son of Perion of Gaul and Elisena of Scotland, was abandoned at birth and set to float, Moses-like, in an arc down a river. He was raised by Gandales of Scotland and as a young child went to serve at the court of his uncle, king Languines of Scotland. There he meets Oriana, also Languines's ward. He becomes a knight at age fifteen. Coincidence allows his father Perion to be the one to knight him, but the monarchs of Gaul do not discover their eldest son's identity until after Amadis's duel with king Abies of Ireland. Amadis is known as the Child of the Sea (Donzel del mar) in the early books, then Amadis when he recovers his name, Beltenebros during his estrangement from Oriana, and the Knight of the Green Sword when he travels to Romania and Constantinople. Amadis has two brothers, illegitimate elder brother Florestan and younger brother Galaor, and a sister, Melicia. He becomes king of Britain and Gaul in the fifth volume of Amadis, Las Sergas de Esplandián. Like Lancelot, Amadis is the best knight in the world until his son replaces him in that role. In the medieval, primitive versions of the legend Amadis is thought to have perished in a duel with Esplandian; the two battled without recognizing each other. In Montalvo's version (the 1508 and all later texts) Amadis survives to marry Oriana, have more children, and rule two kingdoms.

Oriana is the daughter of Lisuarte and Brisena, the heiress apparent to the throne of Britain. She becomes a ward of King Languines of Scotland at ten years old and meets Amadis, then known as the Child of the Sea (Donzel del mar). Amadis soon declares himself her knight, and in secret, their love grows. Oriana rules their relationship, giving Amadis permission to go on adventures or alternately restricting him. They consummate their relationship--by Oriana's decision, not Amadis's--when he saves her from Arcalaus. In Book II Oriana becomes jealous when she believes that Amadis has had a liaison with rival princess Briolania. She writes a letter of dismissal that causes Amadís to fall into a state of love-madness during which he nearly dies of grief. During this phase of the text Amadis is known as Beltenebros. Amadis and Oriana reconcile and have a child together, Esplandian. Whether their liaison counts as a clandestine marriage or is merely illicit is a subject of critical debate. The Oriana of the primitive or medieval Amadis throws herself from a tower when she learns of Amadis's death; the Oriana of the 1508 survives to marry Amadis, become queen of Britain and Gaul, and have more children.

The daughter of Languines of Scotland, sister of Amadis's companion Agrayes and Amadis's first cousin, Mabilia serves Oriana as her most honored lady-in-waiting. Efficient and no-nonsense, she helps conceal Amadis and Oriana's love affair, which could prove fatal to Oriana if discovered. She comforts Oriana in times of trouble, helps hide the infant Esplandian, and writes letters to her cousin Amadis with messages from Oriana. Mabilia marries Grasandor in Book IV as part of the collective wedding Amadis arranges.
A minor knight, Brandoivas serves Lisuarte's court, carrying messages and providing information.
A minor noblewoman, Grindalaya is the lover of King Arban of North Wales, himself a minor character associated with Lisuarte's court. Aldeva is her sister.
Aldeva, a minor female character, is Galaor's lover in Book I. Grindalaya is her sister.
Arban is a minor knight, a sometime companion of Amadis who is associated with Lisuarte's court. Grindalaya is his lover.

Oldest daughter of Garinter, king of Little Britain. She is called the Lady of the Garland, because her husband, King Languines of Scotland, never allowed her to cover her hair but with a chaplet of flowers.
Son of Languines of Scotland. He is Amadis's companion and first cousin as well as a great knight in his own right. He is in love with Olinda la mesurada, a princess of Norway.
Perion's unnamed squire. He assists in the clandestine meetings between Helisena and his master.

Briolanja is first introduced as "la niña hermosa," the beautiful child of the betrayed king of Sobradisa. Amadís helps defeat her uncle Abiseos, who has usurped Briolanja's throne. Thereafter, Briolanja's fate varies according to the version of the legend one follows. Briolanja falls in love with Amadís, and Montalvo cites five versions of the results. Either Amadís rejects her, Amadís indulges in an affair with her (with Oriana's permission) Briolanja imprisons him until he agrees to have a child with him, he either gives in and Briolanja bears twins, or Briolanja relents and allows Amadís to replace himself with Galaor. In the 1508 Briolanja is the occasion for Oriana's jealousy. The dwarf observes that Amadís admires her beauty and misinterprets the fact that Amadís uses the sword she has given him. Oriana's jealousy is based on what she believes to be good information--the dwarf, Amadís's constant companion, tells her he loves the girl who gave him the sword. Briolanja is represented as quite beautiful, and she places second in the beauty challenges at Ínsola Firme. She marries Galaor in Book IV. In Las sergas de Esplandián, Montalvo includes praise for Briolanja, saying that she must have been in fact more beautiful than Oriana.

Amadís's unnamed dwarf is, along with his squire Gandalín, his constant traveling companion. Dwarves appear frequently in chivalric romance, perhaps as the opposite of the giants who are habitual enemies. Amadís's dwarf provides comic relief, and his information is not always sound. He accidentally provokes Oriana's jealousy when he tells her Amadís is in love with Briolanja.

Gandalín, son of Gandales, is Amadís's foster brother and childhood companion. He accompanies Amadís through all his adventures, serving as squire and messenger. Gandalín is a brave fighter who dispatches non-knightly foes, including the giantess Andandona. He briefly becomes governor of Ínsola Firme, inspiring the Barataria episode of Miguel de Cervantes's Don Quixote. Eventually Amadís knights him, finds him a wife, and grants him territory on a permanent basis.
Abiseos is Briolanja's uncle. He usurped the kingdom of Sobradisa from his brother. Amadís and company eventually defeat him.
Darasion is the son of Abiseos, usurper of Briolanja's kingdom of Sobradisa.
Dramis is the son of Abiseos, usurper of Briolanja's kingdom of Sobradisa.
Briolanja's unnamed aunt is a cantankerous personality who nearly gets Amadís killed and sends misleading letters in her quest to restore her niece to the throne of Sobradisa.
Wisest clergyman in Perion's kingdom and counselor of the king.
Another clergyman, counselor/adviser of Perion.
Another clergyman, counselor/adviser of Perion.

We are using anon to signify all of the unnamed characters of the Amadís, which include damsels, squires, giants, hermits, knights, ladies, and other minor characters. If characters are distinct without having a name, like the dwarf or the damsel of Denmark, they have their own xml ids.

Balays of Carsante is grateful to Amadis for rescuing him from the dungeon of the magician Arcalaus. He prevents Galaor and Amadis from unwittingly killing each other by revealing their concealed identities.

place.note: One of the properties that belongs to King Garinter, where he meets Amadis of Gaul's father for the first time.
Angaduza is a forest (floresta) adjacent to the castle of Briolanja's aunt.
Scottish village where Gandales and his family anchor after rescuing Amadis.
Neighboring country of the kingdom of Sobradisa.
King Arthur is said to have defeated Floyon in front of the gates of Paris.
The Knight Gandales carries the infant Amadis by sea to Scotland, to the town Antalia.
Where Amadis says he'll bring Galaor after the two are recovered from their nearly mortal combat. Windsor appears to be the domain of Queen Brisena.
